Dissertation submitted to the  College of Applied Human Sciences At West Virginia University   In partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of     Doctor of Philosophy in Counseling Psychology    Lisa F. Platt, Ph.D., Chair Jeffrey Daniels, Ph.D. Jeneice Shaw, Ph.D. Frankie Tack, M.S., AADC, CCS, NCC    School of Counseling and Well-Being   Morgantown, West Virginia 2023   Keywords: Gender Minority, Adverse Childhood Experiences, Intimate Partner Violence Copyright 2023 Claire Mason McCown  Abstract Adverse Childhood Experiences and Intimate Partner Violence in Gender Minority Populations  Claire Mason McCown, M.P.S.  Childhood adversity has been linked to numerous health and mental health concerns in adulthood (Felitti et al., 1998). Among the many outcomes associated with adverse childhood experiences (ACEs), victimization and perpetration of intimate partner violence (IPV) remains a public health crisis. Research has found that those identifying as gender minority individuals are disproportionately impacted by IPV (Messinger, 2017; Peitzmeier et al., 2020). Further, gender minority individuals experience equivalent, if not higher, rates of ACEs when compared to their cisgender counterparts (Baams, 2018; Juárez-Chávez et al., 2018; Schnarrs et al., 2019; Tobin & Delaney, 2019). While many factors contribute to the pathway from ACEs to IPV, the role of internalized transphobia (IT) in this relation is poorly understood. However, previous research has underscored the role of internalized shame in relation to both ACEs and IPV (Rood et al., 2017; Thaggard & Montayre, 2019; Thomson & Jaque, 2018b). Internalized transphobia may therefore serve as a mediator in the relationship between adverse childhood experiences and intimate partner violence. Using a cross-sectional quantitative single administration survey design, this research aimed to better understand the relation between ACEs, IT, and IPV in adults identifying as gender minorities. This study used a mediated regression model to discern if internalized transphobia mediated the relationship between childhood adversity and intimate partner violence. Findings from this research indicated that while internalized transphobia did not mediate the relationship between ACEs and IPV, IT was still predictive of IPV. Endorsement of ACEs also predicted endorsement of IPV. CHAPTER 1 Adverse Childhood Experiences and Intimate Partner Violence in Gender Minority Populations Intimate Partner Violence-Overview Myriad studies have evaluated the topography of intimate partner violence (IPV) in cisgender and heterosexual populations (Neal & Edwards, 2017; Rauer et al., 2010; Wolford-Clevenger et al., 2016). Intimate partner violence is typically conceptualized within four domains of violence – sexual, psychological, stalking, and physical violence (Breiding et al., 2015; D’Inverno et al., 2019; National Coalition Against Domestic Violence [NCADV], 2020; Smith et al., 2018). Sexual IPV includes sexual coercion, unwanted sexual contact, being forced to penetrate another person, and rape (D’Inverno et al., 2019; Smith et al., 2018). Psychological violence includes coercive control and expressive aggression, such as humiliation tactics and insults.  Stalking behavior broadly consists of habitual threats and harassment that cause a victim to fear for their own safety and/or the safety of others close to them (NCADV, 2020). Stalking can include unwanted following or close physical proximity by the perpetrator, unwanted digital contact, such as phone calls, text messages, or emails, and unwanted gift giving. Finally, stalking may also include breaking into and entering a victim’s home or vehicle for the purpose of scaring the victim or ensuring the victim is aware the perpetrator has violated the victim’s space (Smith et al., 2018). Physical violence is comprised of actions that can cause physical injury, including being hit or kicked by a partner, pulled by the hair, choked or beaten, and harm inflicted by a gun, knife, or other weapon (D’Inverno, 2019; Smith et al., 2018).  Prevalence of IPV in Heterosexual Populations  2 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  In heterosexual populations, IPV has a high prevalence rate. National data indicate that approximately 11% of men and 25% of women have experienced some form of intimate partner violence that led to an IPV-related impact (Smith et al., 2018). Data gathered through the National Intimate Partner and Sexual Violence Survey (NISVS) indicate that roughly 34% and 36% of male and female respondents, respectively, reported a history of experiencing any form of physical or sexual violence or stalking from an intimate partner (Smith et al., 2018).  Over one-third (34.2%) of male respondents on the NISVS endorsed a history of experiencing psychological aggression from an intimate partner.  Roughly 36% of female participants endorsed experiencing any form of psychological IPV and 30.6% reported a history of any form of coercive control. Over 29% of female NISVS respondents reported having been shoved, pushed, or slapped by an intimate partner (Smith et al., 2018). Across men and women, having a partner track their contacts and activities was the most frequently endorsed form of coercive control, with roughly a quarter of men (24.9%) and women (23.5%) endorsing this experience (Smith et al., 2018). A recent study conducted in Canada found that 34% of females and 35% of males in their sample endorsed experiencing high controlling behaviors from an intimate partner (Lysova et al., 2019).  Adverse Impacts of IPV The detrimental impact of intimate partner violence (IPV) is multifaceted, including occupational impairment (LeBlanc et al., 2014), sleep disturbances (Rauer et al., 2010), suicidal ideation (Wolford-Clevenger et al., 2016), depression, anxiety, substance use, and chronic mental illness (Coker et al., 2002). Research has also found that survivors of IPV experience posttraumatic stress symptoms, including situational avoidance, emotional numbing, and hypervigilance (D’Inverno et al., 2019; Lysova et al., 2019). Among cisgender females in higher 3 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  education, IPV victimization was found to be positively correlated with PTSD symptoms, academic disengagement, depression, and adverse academic impacts, such as switching majors (Wood et al., 2020). Additionally, researchers found that as severity of IPV victimization increased, so too did mental health symptoms and academic concerns (Wood et al., 2020). Among sexual minority individuals, shame associated with one’s sexual orientation and IPV victimization experiences contributed to low help-seeking and further victimization (Thaggard & Montayre, 2019). In addition to the psychological impacts of IPV victimization, many survivors also sustain physical injuries of varying degrees of severity. These physical injuries can often intensify subsequent psychological impacts (D’Inverno et al., 2019). Risk Factors for IPV  The high prevalence of IPV has led to increased analysis of risk factors for victimization. In their study, Keenan-Miller and colleagues (2007) found that adolescents who were at risk for intergenerational depression also demonstrated increased risk for severe IPV victimization in young adulthood. Additionally, the researchers found that youth social functioning partially mediated the relation between intergenerational depression risk and prospective risk for severe IPV. These findings demonstrate the need for targeted research on adolescent psychosocial functioning and romantic relationships as a pathway to adult experiences of IPV.   Studies examining IPV in adolescence and young adulthood have identified risk factors for perpetration, including family-of-origin violence (Edwards, et al., 2014), unskilled parenting (Capaldi & Clark, 1998), and substance use (Shorey et al., 2014). Research focusing specifically on cisgender heterosexual men has implicated masculine identity and gender role stress in the perpetration of relationship aggression (Cohn & Zeichner, 2006). In their study, Cohn and Zeichner (2006) found that cisgender heterosexual male participants that strictly adhered to 4 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  social norms of masculine identity evidenced increased aggressive behavior. Similarly, male gender role stress, defined as situational variables influencing presentation intensity of masculine identity, evidenced increased aggressive behavior.   Substance use is also related to the perpetration of IPV. In their 2011 daily diary study, Moore and colleagues found that on drinking days, participants were 2.19 and 3.64 times more likely to commit psychological and physical aggression, respectively, compared to nondrinking days (Moore et al., 2011). Further, male participants demonstrated 7.03 greater odds of committing psychological aggression towards their partners on drinking days, compared with a 1.60 odds ratio among female participants. These findings were replicated in a daily diary study assessing angry affect, marijuana use, and alcohol use in college females (Shorey et al., 2014). In addition to alcohol consumption increasing the odds for psychological and physical aggression perpetration, the researchers found that marijuana use increased the odds of committing psychological aggression (Shorey et al., 2014).  Finally, family functioning has been implicated as a risk factor for perpetration of IPV in cisgender heterosexual individuals. In their 2014 study, Edwards and colleagues found that witnessing or being a victim of violence in the home at an early age led to increased likelihood of IPV perpetration in adolescence and young adulthood. Further, the researchers found that those who experienced sexual or psychological child abuse evidenced hostile-dominant interpersonal problems (HDIP) that significantly predicted perpetration of physical, sexual, and psychological abuse in adolescence and young adulthood (Edwards et al., 2014). In a longitudinal study, researchers found that unskilled parenting practices in childhood predicted antisocial behavior in adolescence, which in turn predicted perpetration of intimate aggression in young adulthood (Capaldi & Clark, 1998). History of child abuse, alcohol and other substance use, and witnessing 5 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  domestic violence in the home similarly predicted IPV in the LGB population as in the cisgender heterosexual population (Craft & Serovich, 2005; Mason et al., 2016).  Of critical importance is the well-documented association between childhood exposure to violence in the home and subsequent intimate partner violence perpetration and victimization (Anderson & Kras, 2005; Jones et al., 2018; Messinger, 2017). Various perspectives have been offered to explicate this association, including social learning theory (Bandura, 1973; Kwong et al., 2003; Messinger et al., 2021), intergenerational transmission of violence (Ehrensaft et al., 2003), and developmental victimology (Finkelhor, 1995). This pathway equifinality underscores the necessity of more nuanced examinations of IPV risk factors across the lifespan.   Despite significant strides in the intervention and prevention methods literature, intimate partner violence continues to be a devastating public health problem that negatively impacts survivors and those around them. Individuals who have experienced violence victimization in their intimate partnership are at a significantly greater risk of intimate partner homicide (NCADV, 2020; Vatnar et al., 2017). Further, those in intimate partnerships in which children are part of the family system may inadvertently perpetuate abuse cycles through the intergenerational transmission of trauma (Kwong et al., 2003). Many individuals who witness violence in the home early and often in childhood come to not only expect, but also accept, violence victimization as a normative facet of adult partnerships (Lee et al., 2016).  Extant research suggests a high prevalence of intimate partner violence victimization, with over a third of both natal females and natal males reporting a history of physical or sexual violence victimization from a partner (Smith et al., 2018). The aftermath of relationship violence can create numerous mental and physical health concerns, including depression and anxiety, low self-esteem and shame, PTSD, and substance use (Coker et al., 2002; Thaggard & Montayre, 6 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  2019; Wolford-Clevenger et al., 2016). Additionally, survivors often experience a variety of functional impairments, such as poor sleep and occupational and academic impairments (LeBlanc et al., 2014; Rauer et al., 2010; Wood et al., 2020). The existing body of literature suggests many factors can contribute to an individual’s overall risk for violence victimization and perpetration in intimate partnerships (Moore et al., 2011; Shorey et al., 2014). Among the many constructs that have been analyzed thus far, family-of-origin violence and personal identity variables appear to play a key role in understanding an individual’s risk for experiencing intimate partner violence across the lifespan (Cohn & Zeichner, 2006; Craft & Serovich, 2005; Edwards et al., 2014; Jones et al., 2018; Mason et al., 2016).  IPV in Gender Minority Communities   Most previous literature on IPV has focused on the victimization experiences of heterosexual women and men. There is also a growing scholarship on the IPV experiences of sexual minority individuals. However, there is a paucity of research exclusively on the IPV considerations for gender minority individuals. Gender minority individuals are those who identify with a gender different from their sex assigned at birth. Those who identify as gender minorities may describe their gender as transgender, genderqueer, agender, or gender fluid, among others. Many researchers have combined sexual and gender minority IPV survivors into a single group, often referring to trans-identifying individuals under the umbrella term of sexual minority individuals or LBGT (Smith et al., 2016). While this categorization has aided LGBT IPV research, the inclusion of gender minority individuals in sexual minority research may obfuscate our clinical understanding of potentially unique transgender IPV experiences.  Unique IPV Features in Gender Minority Populations  7 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS   Some forms of IPV in GM relationships mirror those found in cisgender populations. There are, however, several forms of IPV distinct to GM populations. Psychological IPV includes a wide range of abusive behaviors, including interpersonal isolation, monitoring and stalking, threats, and financial control (Messinger, 2017). For gender minority individuals, financial abuse can also include control of a partner’s access to trans-affirming medical care (Brown & Pantalone, 2011; Cook-Daniels, 2015; Quinn, 2020). Additionally, abusers may force a partner to remain closeted in their gender identity or may forcefully out their partner as transgender (Cook-Daniels, 2015; Woulfe & Goodman, 2018). Verbal slurs, particularly those related to one’s gender identity, are also very common (Brown & Pantalone, 2011).  If a partner in the dyad has children, the abuser may use the children to manipulate, intimidate, and control their gender minority partner (Messinger, 2017). The abuser may threaten to harm the children or take the children away. Further, abusers may tell their GM partners that they are inadequate parents because of their gender identity (Messinger, 2017). Finally, abusers may engage in identity abuse in an attempt to control their partners by shaming them for their various minoritized identities, including race, ability status, age, and immigration and HIV status (Woulfe & Goodman, 2018). Identity abuse may also include attempts by the abuser to isolate their partner from the LGBTQ+ community (Woulfe & Goodman, 2018).   These tactics are often intended to foster shame in those being victimized by questioning the authenticity of an individual’s gender identity (Bornstein et al., 2006; Cook-Daniels, 2015). Many abusers will also highlight specific body parts with which the gender minority partner feels uncomfortable as a means to control and shame the partner. Further, this type of identity abuse often includes deadnaming and the use of incorrect, gender un-affirming pronouns in addition to imposed restrictions on gender presentation (Cook-Daniels, 2015; FORGE, 2013; Messinger, 8 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  2017; Woulfe & Goodman, 2018). Deadnaming occurs when an individual uses a GM person’s name given at birth and does not use their affirmed name (Freeman, 2018). A small body of research indicates that in addition to general physical victimization that has been identified across racial/ethnic, age, and sexual orientation groups, transgender individuals experience physical victimization that targets gendered body parts (Brown & Pantalone, 2011; Messinger, 2017; Quinn, 2020). This type of victimization is likely reflective of an abuser’s desires to humiliate and control their partner by denigrating the partner’s gender identity while physically harming them.   Quinn (2020) delineated five forms of transgender intimate partner violence (T-IPV) to explicate the nuances of identity violence in transgender intimate partnerships, including emotional, identity, isolation, financial, physical, and sexual abuse. While significant overlap exists between transgender and cisgender IPV, scholars contend that T-IPV is comprised of identity-specific forms of violence (Messinger, 2017; Quinn, 2020). Isolation abuse, for example, can include threats to out a partner as transgender as well as efforts to restrict a partner’s access to the gender minority community. Isolation abuse can also include justifications for isolation predicated on the partner’s fear of violence and transphobia outside of the relationship.  Identity abuse can include manipulation, denigration, and denial of a partner’s gender identity. Abusive partners may call into question the authenticity of their partner’s identity, exert control over how and when a partner transitions, and claim that no one will love their partner because of their gender minority identity (Quinn, 2020). Physical T-IPV can include targeting gendered body parts for physical violence and not allowing a partner to heal after transition-related surgeries and procedures. Sexual T-IPV may also target gendered body parts and can include eroticizing gendered body parts with which the partner is uncomfortable or dysphoric 9 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  (Quinn, 2020). As previously mentioned, financial abuse can include restriction to transition-related expenses and gender-affirming products. Forms of emotional abuse are most akin to cisgender heterosexual and cisgender sexual minority IPV and can include manipulation and blame, criticizing one’s partner, and name calling (Quinn, 2020). Estimated Prevalence of IPV in Gender Minority Populations  When considering rates of sexual violence in intimate relationships, transgender and gender nonconforming individuals evidence heightened rates of victimization. A recent study found that between 16% and 73% of gender minority individuals have experienced psychological IPV related to their T/GNC status (Messinger, 2017). When compared to cisgender individuals, gender minority individuals are 1.7 times more likely to experience any form of IPV victimization and are 2.2 times more likely to be physically victimized. Additionally, gender minority individuals are 2.5 times more likely to experience sexual victimization from an intimate partner when compared to cisgender individuals (Peitzmeier et al., 2020). An estimated 59% of transgender and gender nonconforming adolescents reported experiencing psychological intimate partner violence in the past year (Scottish Transgender Alliance, 2010). Approximately 57% of transmales and 79% of transfemales endorsed lifetime psychological IPV (Messinger, 2017; Pitts et al., 2006). Roughly 33% of gender minority individuals in the United States have endorsed a lifetime prevalence of sexual or physical IPV victimization (Keuroghlian et al., 2015; Messinger, 2017).  Global estimates for physical victimization are higher, with 43-46% of transgender and gender nonconforming adults endorsing lifetime prevalence of physical IPV (Nemoto et al., 2011). One study conducted in the United States reported the past year prevalence of sexual IPV among gender minority adolescents to be 61% (Dank et al., 2014; Messinger, 2017). Global 10 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  estimates range from 8% to 47% for intimate partner sexual violence, which includes behaviors ranging from rape to sexual coercion to sexual contact during substance-based incapacitation. It should be noted that forced substance use is yet another IPV tactic, and as such may complexify and multiply the severity and distress experienced by those who are victimized (Messinger, 2017). Further, the topography of sexual IPV enacted towards gender minority individuals underscores the nuances of gender identity abuse. Similar to the physical violence committed against gendered body parts, perpetrators will often engage in nonconsensual sexual contact with the gendered body parts of their partner as a means of sexual control and coercion (Brown & Pantalone, 2011; Cook-Daniels, 2015; FORGE, 2013). Traditional sex roles and gender norms also influence the presentation of sexual IPV, such that perpetrators will call into question the authenticity of their partner’s gender identity or argue that “real” women and men engage in “rough sex” as a means to justify sexual coercion (Bornstein et al., 2006; Cook-Daniels, 2015; Messinger, 2017).   Another unique facet of IPV committed against gender minority individuals is that transgender and gender nonconforming survivors often experience verbal, and sometimes physical and sexual, victimization in a public setting (Guadalupe-Diaz, 2019; Messinger, 2017). The outcomes of intimate partner violence committed against gender minority individuals are multiple and varied. Many survivors report injuries that impact daily functioning and lead to work and school absence (Messinger, 2017). One study found that nearly 30% of gender minority survivors endorsed missing school or work due to IPV victimization (Scottish Transgender Alliance, 2010). The number of gender minority individuals who experience severe physical injuries varies, with estimates ranging from 16 to 42% of T/GNC survivors (Pitts et al., 2006). Furthermore, fear and safety concerns are fairly common, with gender minority 11 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  individuals in both quantitative and qualitative studies endorsing fear in their intimate partnerships (Pitts et al., 2006; Quinn, 2020). Finally, a staggering 76% of transgender and gender nonconforming survivors endorsed mental health concerns associated with intimate partner violence (Scottish Transgender Alliance, 2010).   While previous work has elucidated nuances in LGBQ IPV, little attention has been paid to the experiences of gender minority survivors of IPV. The dearth of research on interpersonal dynamics among the gender minority population is reflective of the lack of resources available to gender minority victims and perpetrators (Edwards et al., 2015). This research therefore aimed to highlight the needs of the gender minority population and inform future policy and intervention work to improve psychological functioning and improve mental healthcare equity.  Adverse Childhood Experiences ACEs Overview  There is evidence that intimate partner violence and early childhood experiences are related. Adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) are broadly conceptualized as exposure to potentially traumatizing events prior to the age of eighteen (Felitti et al., 1998). The original ACEs questionnaire assesses three forms of abuse in childhood and four forms of domestic dysfunction. Child abuse categories include physical, psychological, and contact sexual abuse. Dysfunction in the home is conceptualized as exposure to violence victimization of one’s mother or stepmother, substance use and abuse, criminal behavior, and mental illness (Felitti et al., 1998).   Prevalence of ACEs in General Population The original ACEs study found that over half (52.1%) of respondents endorsed experiencing at least one ACE prior to the age of eighteen, with the bulk (25.6%) of participants 12 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  endorsing exposure to substance use disorders (Felitti et al., 1998). The second most frequently endorsed ACE was contact sexual abuse, with 22.0% of participants endorsing a history of sexual violence in childhood. Recent data analyzed from the second wave of the National Epidemiologic Survey on Alcohol and Related Conditions (NESARC) indicates that over 60% of respondents endorsed a history of exposure to adverse experiences in childhood (Brown et al., 2017). Among college-age participants, a recent study found that nearly one quarter (22%) had been exposed to parental substance use disorders, 16% had experienced childhood sexual abuse, and 23% reported being exposed to two or more ACEs (Forster et al., 2018). Adult respondents in a retrospective Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS) study endorsed even higher rates of ACEs, with 61.6% of respondents endorsing experiencing at least one ACE (Merrick et al., 2018). Nearly one quarter (24.6%) of participants endorsed an ACEs of 3 or more. In this study, Merrick and colleagues (2018) found the highest rate of endorsement for emotional abuse (34.4%), followed by divorce or separation between parents (27.6%), and exposure to substance use disorders in the home (27.6%). Another study conducted with the National Survey of Children’s Health (NSCH) employed a modified form of the ACE instrument (Crouch et al., 2019). In their analysis, Crouch and colleagues (2019) operationalized ACEs to include substance use disorders in the home, incarceration of a member of the home, death of a parent, parental divorce or separation, witnessing violence in the home, witnessing violence in one’s neighborhood, mental illness in the home, financial adversity, and racial/ethnic maltreatment. Across respondents, the most frequently endorsed ACE was financial hardship, with nearly one quarter (22.5%) of respondents indicating that they had experienced difficulty affording basic housing and/or food. Additionally, 13 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  over 20% of participants endorsed a history of parental divorce or separation (Crouch et al., 2019).  Among sexual minority individuals, prevalence of ACEs is even higher. A study conducted with LGBTQ+ youth found that 86% of respondents endorsed having experienced at least one ACE, with 43% of respondents endorsing experiencing four or more ACEs (Craig et al., 2020). This highly elevated percentage is concerning given the well-established link between experiencing four or more ACEs and the subsequent development of health risk behaviors and mental health concerns (Brown et al., 2017; Clements-Nolle et al., 2018; Dube et al., 2001; Felitti et al., 1998; Forster et al., 2018). In 2013, Andersen and Blosnich found significantly higher rates of endorsement of ACEs among sexual minority participants compared to heterosexual respondents. Those identifying as lesbian, gay, or bisexual reported significantly higher frequencies of mental illness in the home, physical, sexual, and psychological abuse, and substance use disorders in the home. Sexual minority respondents also endorsed significantly more exposure to domestic violence, as well as having a member of the home incarcerated and living with someone with mental illness. When compared to heterosexual respondents, bisexual participants reported significantly higher rates of parental divorce or separation. The comparison of parental divorce or separation between heterosexual respondents and those identifying as gay and lesbian was nonsignificant (Andersen & Blosnich, 2013).   Negative Impacts of ACEs Experiences The Adverse Childhood Experiences Study (ACE) sought to explicate not only the prevalence of childhood trauma across the United States, but also clarify the relation between experiences of trauma in childhood and subsequent health behaviors in adulthood (Felitti et al., 1998). The ACE measure is widely implemented in research assessing retrospective reports of 14 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  adversity in childhood and has proffered robust findings regarding the deleterious sequelae of mental and physical health consequences for survivors of childhood trauma (Felitti et al., 1998; van der Kolk, 2014).  Results from adverse childhood experiences studies have found that those who endorse experiencing childhood trauma are significantly more likely to suffer from serious health concerns, including obesity, sexually transmitted infections (STI), cancer, heart diseases, organ failure, and skeletal fractures (Brown et al., 2017; Felitti et al., 1998). Further, those with a history of childhood trauma also evidence disproportionate risk of substance use disorders, depression, and suicidality (Clements-Nolle et al., 2018; Felitti et al., 1998; Forster et al., 2018). These findings are particularly pronounced among sexual and gender minority (SGM) individuals, such that those who identify as LGBTQ+ evidence disproportionate risk for traumatic victimization in childhood and subsequent psychosocial deficits across the lifespan (Andersen & Blosnich, 2013; Austin et al., 2016; Clements-Nolle et al., 2018; Schnarrs et al., 2019; Zou & Andersen, 2015). In 2015, Austin and colleagues reported that the higher prevalence of ACEs among sexual minority respondents may contribute to this population’s elevated risk for poor health behaviors and health outcomes. Among sexual minority respondents, this study found that endorsement of a history of ACEs was significantly associated with depressive symptoms, asthma, disability status, sexual risk behaviors related to HIV, limitations in physical activity due to health concerns, and poor overall mental wellness (Austin et al., 2016)   ACEs in the Gender Minority Population Unique ACEs Among Gender Minority Individuals  15 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  Recent research has found that transgender and gender nonconforming individuals experience equivalent, if not higher rates of adverse childhood experiences compared to their cisgender counterparts (Baams, 2018; Juárez-Chávez et al., 2018; Schnarrs et al., 2019; Tobin & Delaney, 2019). These findings underscore the importance of research analyzing adverse childhood experiences in gender minority populations. Among studies conducted with gender minority participants, research has found that those identifying as transgender are significantly more likely to endorse polyvictimization in childhood and physical and/or psychological childhood abuse compared to cisgender sexual minority and cisgender heterosexual peers (Baams, 2018). Additionally, childhood abuse among those identifying as gender minorities is significantly associated with adult diagnosis of PTSD (Reisner et al., 2016) and endorsement of past-year drug abuse (Scheim et al., 2017). Finally, abuse in childhood has been found to be significantly predictive of suicide attempts, self-harm, and risky sexual behavior among transgender and gender nonconforming individuals (Fernández-Rouco et al., 2016; Taliaferro et al., 2018; Tobin & Delaney, 2019). In a retrospective self-report study conducted with transgender individuals assigned male at birth (AMAB), participants were asked to reflect on their experiences of potentially traumatic events (PTEs), including various forms of childhood abuse, family violence, and intimate partner violence (Shipherd et al., 2011). Participants in this study also indicated the frequency of victimization due to their transgender status. Among those endorsing a history of physical punishment in childhood, nearly half (46%) reported that they suffered this violence victimization because of their transgender status. Almost 60% of respondents endorsed a history of witnessing family violence in childhood related to their transgender status. For those 16 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  endorsing a history of childhood sexual abuse, 27% of participants indicated that they were sexually abused because they are transgender (Shipherd et al., 2011).  A recent qualitative study conducted with transgender women identified themes of gender nonconformity and strict gender stereotypes related to violence in the home and within one’s family of origin (Juarez-Chavez et al., 2018). Transwomen in this study reported being physically and verbally abused by family members due to perceptions that they were effeminate. Rates of childhood sexual violence were similar to Shipherd and colleagues’ (2011) findings, with roughly one-third of participants endorsing a history of sexual violence prior to age eighteen (Juarez-Chavez et al., 2018). The majority of transwomen interviewed in this study reported that sexual violence occurred in the school setting and was typically perpetrated by male students several years their senior. One participant endorsed being sexually abused by a relative in the home in addition to sexual victimization at school. Most participants also identified experiencing homophobic bullying and slurs prior to or during the attack. Participants further endorsed a pattern of forced silencing by perpetrators related to perceived sexual orientation (Juarez-Chavez et al., 2018).  Other research has underscored the role of gender nonconformity in childhood victimization (Baams, 2018; Grossman et al., 2005; Tobin & Delaney, 2019). A recent cross-sectional quantitative study found that for those identifying as transgender or gender nonconforming, higher degrees of gender nonconformity significantly predicted the likelihood of experiencing each form of childhood adversity assessed in the study (Baams, 2018). This study employed a modified ACES to analyze childhood experiences of psychological abuse, physical abuse, sexual abuse by a nonfamily member, sexual abuse by a family member, witnessing intimate partner violence in the home, having a parent or caregiver in prison, and living with 17 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  someone who abused alcohol or drugs. These findings replicate those reported by Grossman and colleagues (2005). In their mixed-methods study, the research team found that higher levels of gender nonconformity in childhood prior to age thirteen was significantly associated with increased endorsement of both psychological and physical abuse.  Another recent quantitative study examined disparities in ACEs between cisgender sexual minority participants and those identifying as gender minorities (Schnarrs et al., 2019). Those endorsing gender minority status were more likely to report having been emotionally abused and/or neglected and physically neglected when compared to cisgender sexual minority respondents.  Prevalence of ACEs in the GM population As previously mentioned, roughly one-third of transgender participants have endorsed a history of sexual victimization in childhood (Juarez-Chavez et al., 2018; Shipherd et al., 2011). Other research has reported higher rates of contact sexual violence in childhood, with 55% of transgender and gender nonconforming respondents endorsing a history of sexual abuse (Gehring & Knudson, 2005). The average age of first sexual victimization was thirteen. Participants also endorsed high rates of other forms of abuse. Over three-quarters of respondents endorsed a history of verbal abuse, including being insulted (81%) and being yelled at by a parent or caregiver (77%). Additionally, over half of this sample endorsed experiences of childhood psychological abuse, with 55% endorsing being made to feel embarrassed by a parent or caregiver in front of other people. Fifty-eight percent of respondents endorsed being made to feel guilty by a parent or caregiver (Gehring & Knudson, 2005).  When compared to cisgender sexual minority individuals, transgender and gender nonconforming participants are more likely to endorse a history of physical neglect, emotional 18 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  neglect, and emotional abuse (Schnarrs et al., 2019). Additionally, gender minority participants in this study were more likely to endorse higher ACEs scores compared to cisgender sexual minority individuals. This finding is concerning given the already elevated number of ACEs endorsed by sexual minority individuals in previous research (Andersen & Blosnich, 2013; Austin et al., 2016). In a study analyzing HIV sexual risk among female-to-male transgender adults, half of the sample endorsed a history of sexual and/or physical abuse prior to age fifteen (Reisner et al., 2016b)  In 2018, Baams found that when compared to heterosexual respondents, those identifying as gender minority individuals were significantly more likely to report each form of childhood adversity, including sexual, physical, and psychological abuse, problematic substance use in the home, witnessing intimate partner violence in the home, and parental or guardian imprisonment. These findings underscore the pervasive nature of mental and emotional abuse among this population, such that transgender and gender nonconforming respondents were nearly three times as likely to endorse being psychologically abused compared to heterosexual participants.  Importantly, rates of polyvictimization have been found to be significantly higher among gender minority individuals when compared to cisgender individuals, both sexual minority participants and those identifying as heterosexual (Baams, 2018; Sterzing et al., 2017). Sterzing and colleagues (2017) found that adolescents endorsing gender minority status reported significantly higher rates of various types of victimization, including sexual violence, child maltreatment, and school-based bullying, among others. When compared to cisgender males, transfemales reported significantly more cyberbullying victimization and exposure to victimization. Transmales endorsed higher rates of property victimization, with nearly 73% of respondents endorsing past-year property damage. Genderqueer individuals assigned male at 19 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  birth (AMAB) evidenced significantly higher rates of past-year sexual violence and bias-motivated physical violence victimization. Genderqueer participants assigned female at birth (AFAB) evidenced significantly higher rates of child maltreatment and sexual victimization compared to cisgender male respondents. Finally, Sterzing and colleagues (2017) identified polyvictimization as endorsement of ten or more different past-year victimization experiences. Across identity groups, those endorsing gender minority status were significantly more likely to be identified as polyvictimized, with 63.4% of transfemales endorsing ten or more past-year victimization experiences. Nearly half of transmales (48.9%) and genderqueer AFAB (49.5%) were identified as polyvictimized. Finally, 71.5% of genderqueer AMAB were identified as polyvictimized.  Relationship of ACEs and IPV Pathways from ACEs to IPV have been identified, both for perpetration behaviors and victimization experiences, among samples in the United States and internationally (Afifi et al., 2017; Bellis et al., 2014; Miller et al., 2011). In a study assessing health-harming behaviors conducted with participants living in England, researchers found the prevalence of violence victimization and perpetration to be five times higher among those endorsing an ACES score of 4 or higher (Bellis et al., 2014). This study utilized a 11-item short ACE tool that separated items into nine distinct ACE categories. Scores on the short ACE ranged from 0 to 9 (Bellis et al., 2014). In the United States, rates of physical dating violence victimization and perpetration were significantly associated with ACEs. Individuals who endorsed a history of childhood sexual abuse, interparental violence, and parental mental illness were at a significantly greater risk of enacting or receiving physical dating violence. Further, risk of physical dating violence 20 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  victimization and perpetration were both significantly increased for those endorsing additional experiences of childhood adversity (Miller et al., 2011).  Other research has supported this association. Afifi and colleagues (2017) found an association between harsh physical punishment in childhood and intimate partner violence perpetration and victimization. Harsh physical punishment was operationalized as being pushed, shoved, slapped, hit, or grabbed by a parent or adult in the home prior to age 18. Harsh physical punishment in childhood was also found to be predictive of reciprocal IPV in adulthood (Afifi et al., 2017). Finally, harsh physical punishment in childhood was predictive of each form of childhood abuse, including sexual, physical, and emotional abuse, as well as physical and emotional neglect. This finding is significant as it underscores the vast range of childhood adversities found to increase one’s risk of IPV experiences in adulthood. Other research has reported natal sex-based differences in the contributions of ACEs to IPV perpetration (Brown et al., 2017). Specifically, the authors reported a direct association between sexual abuse and IPV perpetration among natal males. Among natal women, childhood neglect, physical abuse, and psychological abuse significantly predicted IPV perpetration in adulthood. In their full mediation model, only childhood sexual abuse demonstrated significance in predicting intimate partner violence perpetration among men. There were no statistically significant predictors of intimate partner violence perpetration among the natal female sample (Brown et al., 2017).   Research conducted with pregnant women has also found an association between physical and sexual abuse in childhood and intimate partner violence victimization in adulthood (Barrios et al., 2015). Those who endorsed experiencing both sexual and physical abuse in childhood evidenced a 7.14 times higher risk of experiencing sexual or physical IPV across the lifespan. Further, those endorsing both physical and sexual abuse in childhood were at a 3.33 21 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  times increased risk of experiencing past-year sexual or physical intimate partner violence (Barrios et al., 2015). Among men, a recent meta-analysis found a significant association between different forms of childhood maltreatment and intimate partner violence in adulthood. This association was significant for perpetrators of IPV and survivors of relationship violence (Godbout et al., 2019).   Social learning theory has been employed as a foundational theory to contextualize the intergenerational transmission of violence victimization and perpetration within one’s family-of-origin (Messinger, 2017). In this frame, children are thought to be socialized into accepting violence as part of their lived experiences. For some children, this may lead to the perpetuation of violence in adulthood in the context of romantic relationships. Others may normalize violence in adulthood victimization. Legal scholars have provided support for this theory, indicating that individuals exposed to childhood adversity adopt perpetrator and victim identities in adulthood as a function of family-of-origin social learning (Anderson & Kras, 2005). Specifically, Anderson and Kras (2005) underscore the malleability of values and perceptions of normalcy in childhood. While children may internally experience distress related to their adverse experiences, patterns of family behavior can set a precedent of acceptance of violence in the home and a chaotic environment. As adults, these same individuals may rationalize and accept their experiences with violence given the modeling of violence they witnessed during childhood.  In a 2011 study conducted with gender minority adults, Shipherd and colleagues found that nearly 60% of those endorsing intimate partner violence victimization indicated that they had been victimized due to their transgender identity. Another study conducted with transgender adults reported similar findings (White Hughto et al., 2017), indicating that those who endorsed a history of exposure to family violence were more likely to report intimate partner violence 22 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  victimization in adulthood. Similarly, those endorsing a history of physical and verbal abuse from their family of origin were more likely to endorse experiencing physical or sexual IPV victimization. Finally, White Hughto and colleagues (2017) found that history of childhood sexual abuse predicted adult IPV victimization.   Another recent study conducted with female-assigned-at-birth sexual and gender minority individuals (FAB SGM) found support for the theory of intergenerational violence transmission stemming from one’s family-of-origin (Messinger et al., 2021). In their study, Messinger and colleagues (2021) found significant associations between various forms of childhood violence exposure (CVE) and adult physical, sexual, and psychological intimate partner violence victimization and perpetration. Based in social learning theory, the research team found a similar pattern of violence victimization and perpetration in gender minority individuals as has been previously found among cisgender people (Anderson & Kras, 2005; Messinger et al., 2021).  Specifically, physical abuse and verbal maltreatment were both found to be independently predictive of physical and psychological IPV perpetration and victimization. Verbal maltreatment and physical abuse were also found to predict sexual IPV victimization. Childhood sexual abuse was found to predict each form of IPV perpetration and victimization aside from psychological IPV perpetration. Witnessing IPV between parents during childhood was also significantly predictive of each form of IPV, with the exception of sexual IPV victimization. Further, witnessing sibling abuse by a parent was significantly associated with each form of IPV aside from physical victimization and perpetration (Messinger et al., 2021). Interestingly, the research team found a mismatch in intergenerational transmission of typologies of violence, such that childhood physical abuse was more significantly associated with psychological IPV perpetration and victimization than physical perpetration and victimization. 23 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  The cumulative effect of childhood violence exposure was particularly pronounced as well. Participants reporting higher numbers of childhood violence exposures evidenced incrementally increasing risk of endorsing each form of IPV perpetration and victimization (Messinger et al., 2021).  Internalized Transphobia Internalized Transphobia- Overview Definition   In addition to the external stressors, discrimination, and violence victimization suffered by individuals identifying as gender minorities, those with diverse gender identities often must also contend with internalized shame related to their gender identities. Internalized transphobia (IT) is broadly defined as the process by which an individual incorporates discriminatory and prejudiced views regarding their gender identity into their own self-concept (Bockting et al., 2020; McLean, 2021). IT can include the adoption of transphobic beliefs about the self and can also propagate feelings of shame and low self-worth, along with a host of negative mental health consequences (Cronin et al., 2019; McLean, 2021; Staples et al., 2018). IT stems from overarching cultural cissexism that denigrates the identities of GM individuals. The systemic nature of internalized transphobia permeates multiple spheres of existence, meaning that individuals who experience IT often suffer external marginalization and subsequent devaluing of the self across contexts. The internalization of transphobic attitudes negatively impacts mental and physical health as well as overall quality of life, work outcomes, and interpersonal relationships (Lee et al., 2020; Mizock et al., 2017; Rood et al., 2017; Testa et al., 2017).  Adverse impacts of IT 24 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS   Internalized transphobia has been linked to numerous adverse impacts across multiple domains of functioning, including occupational impairment (Mizock & Mueser, 2014; Mizock et al., 2018; Mizock et al., 2017; Scandurra & Bochicchio, 2018), depression (Lee et al., 2020), maladaptive coping (Ashraf & Khan, 2019), and social and interpersonal concerns (Cronin et al., 2019; Rood et al., 2017). Further, extant research has found links between IT and disordered eating behavior (Parker & Harriger, 2020; Uniacke et al., 2021) as well as nonsuicidal self-injurious behaviors (NSSIB), suicidal ideation, and suicide attempts (Kota et al., 2020; Lee et al., 2020; Staples et al., 2018; Testa et al., 2017).   Gender minority individuals experience numerous barriers in the workplace related to their gender identities, including intersectional discrimination, gender policing and lack of inclusive workplace policies, and internalized transphobia (Mizock et al., 2018). A recent qualitative study conducted in 2018 with transgender and gender nonconforming adults employed thematic coding to analyze the role of various minority stressors in the workplace. Scandurra and Bochicchio (2018) found that experiences of internalized transphobia predominated the work sphere. Participants in the study reported that experiencing IT led to identity concealment in the workplace as well as conformity to gender role expectations. Participants endorsed internalizing gendered stereotypes and expectations to the extent of hypermasculine and hyperfeminine self-presentations that felt incongruent with their sense of self. Across participants, many reported feeling an internal pressure to reject and conceal their transgender or gender nonconforming identity due to perceptions that they would not be accepted by others. Many individuals in the study reported intense feelings of distress and discomfort, not only with concealing their gender minority identities, but also with their identities themselves (Scandurra & Bochicchio, 2018).  25 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  In 2014, Mizock and Mueser reported similar findings in a quantitative analysis of internalized transphobia, coping, and employment among transgender and gender nonconforming participants. Contrary to their hypotheses, Mizock and Mueser (2014) found that employed participants reported higher rates of IT compared to unemployed respondents. The authors postulated that those who endorsed being employed experienced higher rates of IT due to daily exposures to external transphobia in the workplace. The research team also found that the utilization of coping strategies was related to lower levels of internalized transphobia. Experiences of IT in the workplace can also lead to decreased engagement in work-related activities (Mizock et al., 2017). Internalized transphobia has also been found to be predictive of depressive symptoms (Ashraf & Khan, 2019; Lee et al., 2020). In a study conducted with GM participants in South Korea, researchers utilized a Korean-translated version of the Gender Minority Stress and Resilience measure (GMSR) to assess the relation between IT and mental health outcomes (Lee et al., 2020). The research team found IT significantly and positively predicted mental health sequelae, such that those endorsing higher degrees of IT also endorsed higher rates of depressive symptoms. Additionally, those endorsing higher degrees of IT reported significantly more suicidal ideation and history of suicide attempts (Lee et al., 2020). Other research employing the minority stress framework has supported this finding (Kota et al., 2020; Staples et al., 2018; Testa et al., 2017). In 2018, Staples and colleagues found that internalized transnegativity operated as both a moderator and mediator in the relation between distal gender minority stressors and nonsuicidal self-injurious behavior and suicidal ideation. Using the GMSR, Testa and colleagues (2017) conducted a path analysis to understand the relation between distal gender minority stress, IT, 26 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  and suicidality. The research team reported significance in two of their models, such that IT mediated the relation between victimization, rejection, and non-affirmation and suicidal ideation. The second model demonstrated that IT was predictive of suicidal ideation through interpersonal-psychological theory of suicide (IPTS) factors (Testa et al., 2017). Finally, using the Transgender Identity Survey (TIS) to assess IT, Perez-Brumer and colleagues (2015) found that elevated scores on the TIS were significantly associated with an increased likelihood of suicide attempts across the lifespan.   A recent international study conducted in Pakistan in 2019 assessed the mediating role of coping strategies in the relation between internalized transphobia and common mental health disorders, including somatic concerns, anxiety, and depression, as well as low frustration tolerance (Ashraf & Khan, 2019). The research team found that internalized transphobia was predictive of avoidant coping and each of the abovementioned mental health concerns. Similarly, in the qualitative component of their two-part study, Mizock and Mueser (2014) found that many participants endorsed utilizing disengagement coping as a way of avoiding difficult emotions surrounding internalized and external transphobia. Additionally, other work has posited that maladaptive coping strategies can lead to self-stigma, such as internalized transphobia (Mizock et al., 2017). In the face of workplace transphobia, participants endorsed maladaptive coping strategies that provided short-term relief from a transphobic work environment. However, these strategies can ultimately contribute to longer-term mental health concerns. Participants in Mizock and Mueser’s study (2014) endorsed using disengagement coping by avoiding interpersonal relationships due to fear of rejection related to their gender minority status. These individuals reported that internalized transphobia as well as societal transphobia contributed to their interpersonal avoidance. Theorists have also posited that interpersonal 27 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  rejection during transition can lead to greater internalized transphobia, which can in turn contribute to greater interpersonal isolation and alienation (McLean, 2021). Cronin and colleagues (2019) have postulated that secure attachment can serve as a safeguard against the impact of IT on mental health concerns, such that those who demonstrate secure attachment are better able to recognize and decrease the intensity of IT cognitions. In their study, Cronin and colleagues (2019) found IT to be positively associated with both attachment avoidance and attachment anxiety. IT was independently predictive of decreased life satisfaction. The interaction between IT and attachment avoidance, as well as the interaction between IT and attachment anxiety, were also significantly associated with decreased life satisfaction (Cronin et al., 2019). While individuals in transition may access support from other gender minority people, the longevity of relationships pre-transition is often compromised and can contribute to greater internalized transphobia. Recent research suggests that while social connectedness is significantly and positively associated with self-esteem among GM adults, the strength of the association between IT and low self-esteem remains (Austin & Goodman, 2017). It appears that social support does not provide a viable buffer against the insidious nature of internalized transphobia. Further, recent research has found that social collective action strengthened the relation between IT and psychological distress (Breslow et al., 2015). Finally, social messages from the larger cisnormative society have been found to contribute to elevated levels of IT. Participants in a recent qualitative study reported feelings of shame regarding their gender minority identity and body image as well as expectations for victimization and delayed transition (Rood et al., 2017). 28 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS   Research has found that those identifying as GM evidence elevated rates of disordered eating when compared to cisgender peers (Parker & Harriger, 2020; Uniacke et al., 2021). In one study, over half of participants described a lifetime history of disordered eating behaviors (Uniacke et al., 2021). Further, the majority of participants endorsed past-year elevated weight and shape concerns tied to self-concept and approximately 60% of respondents endorsed past-year restriction eating behaviors related to shape concerns. The research team also found that as internalized transphobia increased, so too did the risk of disordered eating behaviors (Uniacke et al., 2021). Those who endorsed higher transgender congruence, defined as external alignment between one’s gender identity and appearance, demonstrated lower levels of eating pathology. Those with low transgender congruence may therefore exhibit increased body dissatisfaction and internalized transphobia that contribute to increased risk of eating pathology (Parker & Harriger, 2020). Internalized Transphobia, ACEs, and IPV  Given the association between ACEs and IPV, as well as IT and IPV, it stands to reason that a relation among all three variables exists. Within the general population, research has supported the association between childhood adversity and violence victimization in adulthood (Messinger et al., 2021; Miller et al., 2011). Additionally, research has supported the role of internalized shame in IPV and ACEs (Scheer et al., 2019; Thomson & Jaque, 2018b). Individuals identifying as GM experience unique stressors related to their gender identity, often leading to internalized transphobia (Cronin et al., 2019; McLean, 2021; Staples et al., 2018). Understanding the relation between adverse childhood experiences and internalized transphobia is critical in illuminating pathways that contribute to mental health concerns among an already highly minoritized and at-risk population. Recent research has indicated a significant relation between 29 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  internalized stigma and childhood adversity. Among women living with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), participants reported an average ACES score of 4.2 out of 10 (Cuca et al., 2019). Over half (58.3%) of participants reported experiencing four or more ACEs. The research team also employed a lifetime trauma instrument and found that 97.1% of respondents endorsed experiencing any traumatic event from childhood to adulthood. Cuca and colleagues (2019) found a statistically significant association between lifetime trauma exposure and internalized HIV stigma. Four transgender and intersex women were included in the study with a sample size of 104. Another recent study conducted with GM youth found that family-based emotional neglect and internalized sexual orientation and gender identity self-stigma significantly predicted past 6-month suicidality (Austin et al., 2020).  Further, a recent physical health study reported a significant positive association between total ACEs and internalized weight stigma in women with overweight/obesity, such that women who endorsed a higher number of ACEs also reported more internalized weight stigma (Keirns et al., 2021). Across ACEs typologies, abuse-type ACEs were significantly predictive of internalized weight stigma. Self-reports of internalized shame were significantly elevated among pre-professional and professional dancers with higher ACES scores (Thomson & Jaque, 2018b). Participants in the high internalized shame group with higher ACES scores endorsed significantly more experiences of sexual, emotional, and physical abuse as well as emotional neglect. When compared to the low internalized shame category, those with higher levels of internalized shame also demonstrated clinical degrees of low self-esteem and anxiety. The authors identified significance in their causal pathway model, demonstrating that ACEs exhibited a direct effect on internalized shame in adulthood (Thomson & Jaque, 2018b). In another study of performing arts professionals, those with an ACES score of 4 or higher out of 10 total ACE 30 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  items were significantly more likely to endorse higher levels of internalized shame (Thomson & Jaque, 2018a).   Thus, it appears that experiences of childhood adversity may lead to various forms of internalized stigma, which can then contribute to myriad health complications, mental health concerns, and interpersonal dysfunction. This relation may be especially heightened for ACEs that are typically imbued with shame. Individuals who have experienced sexual abuse, verbal victimization, and emotional or psychological abuse may demonstrate an elevated risk of internalized shame, both generally and as it pertains to various minoritized identities. Therefore, among gender minority individuals, a history of shame-inducing ACEs likely contributes to elevated internalized transphobia in adulthood.   Internalized transphobia can also contribute to subsequent interpersonal victimization. Such an association has been found among sexual minority women. In a vignette study assessing perceptions of psychological IPV, researchers found that higher endorsement of internalized sexual minority stigma predicted permissive attitudes towards perpetration of intimate partner psychological abuse (Islam, 2021). Badenes-Ribera and colleagues (2019) completed a meta-analysis on the existing literature analyzing internalized stigma and intimate partner violence among sexual minority individuals. The research team reported statistically significant positive correlations between internalized homophobia and both intimate partner violence perpetration and victimization. These findings held true for each form of IPV, including physical, sexual, and psychological violence (Badenes-Ribera et al., 2019). Across studies analyzed in the meta-analysis, participants endorsing higher rates of internalized homophobia also endorsed higher rates of IPV victimization and perpetration behaviors. The research team postulated that internalized homophobia may be differentially associated with intimate partner violence. For 31 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  some sexual minority respondents, internalization of negative perceptions regarding one’s sexual minority status may lead to the enactment of violence towards their partners. However, other sexual minority individuals with high internalized homophobia may adopt the perception that they are worthy of abuse in intimate relationships and therefore view intimate partner victimization as integral to their minoritized sexual orientation identity (Badenes-Ribera et al., 2019).   The abovementioned processes are likely also present in the intimate relationships of gender minority individuals. Given the similarities in minority stress pathways between sexual and gender minority individuals (Hendricks & Testa, 2012; Meyer, 2003), it is likely that gender minority individuals evidence similar internalizations of shame related to their minoritized identities. Experiences of internalized transphobia can then lead to violence in intimate relationships. Broadly, shame often contributes to an inclination to withdraw, seclude, and hide parts of oneself or one’s lived experiences. Identity-based shame similarly leads to concealment of various identities. Through this process, individuals who experience violence victimization in intimate partnerships often develop the perception that they are deserving of abuse due to their minoritized identities. Experiences of systemic discrimination, stigma, and violence contribute to the erroneous perception that one is worthy of IPV related to GM identity. Research is needed to better understand nuances in the relation between internalized stigma and intimate partner violence for GM individuals.  Critical Gap Most past literature examining IPV is focused on cisgender heterosexual individuals (Neal & Edwards, 2017; Rauer et al., 2010; Wolford-Clevenger et al., 2016). Empirical investigation with sexual minority groups has elucidated the health disparities and unique 32 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  experiences of the LGBQ population but is largely retrospective in nature and fails to distinguish between those identifying as sexual and gender minorities. Research on gender minority individuals has, for the most part, been subsumed under the umbrella of sexual minority literature. A critical gap is present in our ambiguous clinical understanding of the gender minority experience with IPV. Given the disproportionate rates of violence, adverse childhood experiences, victimization, and deleterious sequelae of psychosocial impairments in this community, it is vital that IPV research focus specifically on the lived experiences of GM individuals. This study therefore served to explicate the relation among adverse childhood experiences (ACEs), internalized transphobia (IT), and intimate partner violence (IPV) experiences among gender minority individuals. Findings from this work added to the existing body of literature on GM IPV and have the potential to inform future public health efforts for relationship violence prevention and intervention. Given the nuances of GM IPV, it is critical that prevention and intervention efforts are designed specifically for the needs of this highly underserved population. Of primary importance is a grounded understanding of not only typologies of gender minority intimate partner violence, but also an understanding of systemic factors that may contribute to both violence victimization and perpetration. The low help-seeking rates of GM survivors of interpersonal violence is well-established in the literature (Guadalupe-Diaz & Jasinski, 2016; Scheer et al., 2020). Expectations of stigma and discriminatory experiences within systems designed to help and provide care often prevent GM survivors from exiting violent relationships and seeking supportive services (Scheer et al., 2020).  Gender minority survivors may also exhibit a strong sense of shame, not only related to their experiences of victimization, but also their minoritized gender identity. This study intended 33 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  to provide insight into the role of IT in the relation between ACEs and IPV. By understanding how internalized transphobia can develop after childhood adversity, future research can explore methods of decreasing IT after experiencing trauma at a young age. Additionally, this work informs future intervention methodologies that target decreasing IT to promote adaptive interpersonal functioning within the context of intimate partnerships. Taken together, this research informs subsequent research and interventions that attenuate the sequelae of mental health outcomes and maladaptive interpersonal dynamics related to childhood trauma among gender minority individuals.     This study employed a quantitative cross-sectional single distribution survey design to assess the mediating role of internalized transphobia in the relation between adverse childhood experiences and intimate partner violence. It was hypothesized that: H1: There will be a significant, positive correlation between adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) and IPV experiences in adulthood.   This was tested first by a bivariate correlation analysis. The regression models also tested this hypothesis.   H2: There will be a significant, positive correlation between IT and IPV experiences in adulthood.  This was tested first by a bivariate correlation analysis. The regression models also tested this hypothesis.   H3: The relationship between adverse childhood experiences and intimate partner violence will be mediated by internalized transphobia.   This was tested with the regression models.   34 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  CHAPTER 2 Method Overview  This research aimed to explore the relationships among adverse childhood experiences, internalized transphobia, and intimate partner violence in gender minority adults. Previous research has provided insight into IPV dynamics in cisgender heterosexual individuals (Neal & Edwards, 2017; Rauer et al., 2010; Wolford-Clevenger et al., 2016) as well as those identifying as sexual minorities (Mason et al., 2016). Less is known about the nuances of intimate partner violence among GM individuals. Additionally, research has explored the relation between adverse childhood experiences and internalized shame (Scheer et al., 2019; Thomson & Jaque, 2018b) as well as childhood adversity to IPV (Messinger et al., 2021; Miller et al., 2011). The role of internalized shame in the relation between ACEs and IPV among those identifying as GM is less clear. This study therefore aimed to explicate this relation using a cross-sectional, single-distribution, quantitative survey design with instruments assessing childhood adversity, internalized transphobia, and intimate partner violence. It should be noted that language pertaining to identity is ever-evolving. As culture shifts and changes over time, so too does the language people use to describe their identities. The language used in this research is purposefully broad to be inclusive of a wide range of identifiers. The phrase gender minority, or GM, is used throughout this manuscript for this purpose. While the term gender minority is a current and widely used term at the time of writing, this author recognizes that cultural shifts in identity terms may render this phrase obsolete after publication.
