The instruments described below were selected for their relevance to the research question, rigorous scale development, brevity, and utility. The final instrument described below is an 8-item demographics questionnaire that was used to provide descriptive statistics about the sample in addition to measuring control variables.  The Revised Conflict Tactics Scales Short Form (CTS2S; Straus & Douglas, 2004) To assess the outcome variable, IPV victimization, participants completed The Revised Conflict Tactics Scales Short Form (CTS2S; Straus & Douglas, 2004, See Appendix A). The CTS2S is widely used to evaluate physical, sexual, and emotional violence in intimate relationships. The CTS2S includes 20 items that separate conflict tactics experiences into five 39 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  classifications: physical assault, assault with injury, sexual coercion, negotiation, and psychological aggression. The original CTS2 is comprised of 78 items, but for brevity, the CTS2 Short Form was used.   The authors reported an instrument completion time of approximately three minutes, making the CTS2S a brief measure for research. Sample items on the CTS2S include, “My partner insulted or swore or shouted or yelled at me” and “My partner used force (like hitting, holding down, or using a weapon) to make me have sex.” Score responses are measured on an 8-point frequency scale, with a response of 1 reflecting that an item happened “Once in the past year.” A response of 4 indicates “6-10 times in the past year” and a response of 6 corresponds to “More than 20 times in the past year.” A score of 7 indicates that an item happened “Not in the past year, but it did happen before” and a score of 8 indicates that “This has never happened.”  Scoring each item is conducted by summing the midpoints for response options selected by participants. Answer categories are first converted from the 1- to 8-point frequency to a 0 to 7 score (Straus et al., 1996). The midpoint for response options 0, 1, and 2 are therefore the same as the numbers for the response categories (8, recoded as 0 = This has never happened; 1 = Once in the past year; 2 = Twice in the past year). The midpoint for category 3 (3-5 times in the past year) is 4, the midpoint for category 4 (6-10 times in the past year) is 8, and the midpoint for category 5 (11-20 times in the past year) is 15. The authors recommend using a midpoint of 25 for category 6 (More than 20 times in the past year) (Straus et al., 1996). Category 7 (Not in the past year, but it did happen before) can be coded for lifetime prevalence with a score of 1 or coded as 0 to identify no past year prevalence. For the purposes of the current study, lifetime prevalence scoring was used, meaning that those who respond to items with the number 7 were 40 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  coded as a score of 1. Those who endorse no past year prevalence for a given item were scored as 0. The research team who created the CTS2 reported good internal consistency reliability, as evidenced by the congruence of each item selected for subscales of the CTS2. The Psychological Aggression subscale had the lowest internal consistency reliability with an alpha of 0.79. Both the Negotiation and Physical Assault subscales had an alpha of 0.86, while the Sexual Coercion subscale demonstrated an alpha of 0.87. The highest internal consistency reliability was found on the Injury subscale, with a Cronbach’s alpha of 0.95 (Straus et al., 1996).  Concurrent validity was established via correlations between the CTS2 and the approximation iteration of the CTS2S. The CTS2S is considered an approximation due to the augmentation of items to avoid underreporting. Items were expanded to clarify and specify different behaviors that would fall under different violence classifications. On the Severe Assault scale, for example, the item “Beat up my partner” was modified to read, “Punched or kicked or beat up my partner” (Straus & Douglas, 2004). The authors reported concurrent validity via correlations between the CTS2 and the CTS2S. The lowest correlation was found on the Sexual Coercion scale, with r = .67 for Sexual Coercion by the partner and r = .65 for Sexual Coercion by the respondent. The highest correlation was found on the Injury scale, with both respondent and partner evidencing r = .94.  Construct validity for the CTS2S was provided via correlations with four of the risk factors identified by the Personal and Relationships Profile (PRP; Straus & Mouradian, 1999), including Criminal History, Couple Conflict, Anger Management, and Violence Approval. The authors provided evidentiary support for the construct validity of the CTS2S via conceptual 41 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  equivalency to the CTS2 and the CTS2’s correlations with the aforementioned risk factors. However, it must be noted that only partial correlations were obtained for the risk factors on the CTS2S given that the psychometric study was conducted with individual participants in lieu of romantically involved participant dyads.  The coefficients reported by Straus and Douglas (2004) indicate a high correlation between the constructs assessed on the full CTS2 and the shortened CTS2S. Construct validity for the short form of the CTS2 was discerned by computing partial correlations between the short and long forms of the CTS2 and the five risk factors for IPV identified on the Personal and Relationships Profile (Straus & Mouradian, 1999). Of the pairs of correlations computed, only one correlation reached statistical significance, thus indicating a difference between the CTS2 and the CTS2S. The correlation between Negative Attributions on the PRP and psychological aggression towards a partner was significantly lower (r = .04) on the short form compared to the long form (r = .19). These correlations reached significance at the .001 level and denote conceptual equivalence and construct validity between the long and short forms of the CTS2, with the exception of the correlation for Negative Attributions.  The validity of the CTS2S was further assessed via prevalence rates for endorsing specific conflict behaviors. When compared to the long form, the CTS2S resulted in lower endorsement of each conflict behavior. This finding is reflective of the principle that the diversity of items included in a behavioral measure is directly related to the prevalence rate of the behaviors. As items are winnowed down for conservation of time and simplicity, the prevalence rate decreases as well. The total score on the CTS2S served as the criterion variable in the current analyses. The Cronbach’s alpha for the current study was 0.80, as seen in Table 2. Adverse Childhood Experiences Survey (ACES; Felitti et al., 1998) 42 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  The Adverse Childhood Experiences Survey (ACES; Felitti et al., 1998) is a measure of exposure to household dysfunction and childhood abuse. This measure served as a predictor variable in the current study (see Appendix B). The ACES is a 17-item binary response (Y/N) measure, with higher scores indicating endorsement of exposure to a greater number of traumatic childhood events. Individuals respond to items such as, “Did a parent or other adult in the household often or very often swear at, insult, or put you down?” and, “Was your mother or stepmother sometimes, often, or very often kicked, bitten, hit with a fist, or hit with something hard?” The instrument includes three types of childhood abuse categories, including Physical, Psychological, and Contact Sexual. The ACES also includes four types of exposure to dysfunction in the household, including Violent Treatment of Mother or Stepmother, Criminal Behavior, Mental Illness, and Substance Abuse. Individuals who respond with the “yes” option are identified as having been exposed to a specific category of dysfunction or abuse. Total scores are computed by summing the number of “yes” responses across items. The number of potential exposures therefore ranges from 0 (unexposed) to 7 (exposed to all categories).  Bethell and colleagues (2017) proposed that cumulative scoring is most appropriate for the ACES. Cumulative scoring was employed in the current study. Research conducted with the ACES has consistently reported a dose-response effect for exposure to adversity in childhood and various physical and mental health concerns in adulthood (Dube et al., 2004; Felitti et al., 1998). An ACES score of four or more has been identified as the critical cutoff for increasing one’s risk for mental and physical health concerns in adulthood (Felitti et al., 1998).  Ford and colleagues (2014) reported acceptable Cronbach’s alphas in their ACES factor analysis study. Internal consistency reliability was highest for the Sexual Abuse subscale and the overall ACES score, both of which were reported as 0.80. The authors reported a Cronbach’s 43 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  alpha coefficient of 0.61 for Household Dysfunction. Ford and colleagues also reported a Cronbach’s alpha coefficient of 0.78 for the total ACES measure, indicating that each item identifies an adverse childhood experience and that the items are overall related to one another. Bethell and colleagues (2017) reported similar evidence of reliability in their study comparing the psychometric properties of different versions of the ACES, identifying no reliability or validity concerns for any ACES form. Using a 10-item version of the ACES, Esaki and Larkin (2013) reported a Cronbach’s alpha of 0.73. Research conducted with an international version of the ACES in Nigeria reported a Cronbach’s alpha of 0.80 (Kazeem, 2015).  In 2004, Dube and colleagues assessed the test-retest reliability of the ACES, reporting kappa coefficients for different abuse categories with the same respondents over an average of 20 months between waves I and II. The researchers reported a kappa coefficient of .69 for sexual abuse (95% CI, .61-.77), .55 for physical abuse (95% CI, .47-.63), and .66 for emotional abuse (95% CI, .55-.76). Additionally, the researchers reported test-retest reliability across a twenty-month span for household dysfunction items, reporting a kappa coefficient of .46 for incarcerated household members (95% CI, .27-.65) and .51 for mental illness in the home (95% CI, .42-.61). The kappa coefficient for parent divorce or separation was reported as .86 (95% CI, .81-.91) and the kappa coefficient for household substance use was .75 (95% CI, .68-.81). Finally, the kappa coefficient for maternal figure being treated violently was .77 (95% CI, .68-.85) (Dube et al., 2004).  Additionally, other researchers employed confirmatory factor analysis to assess the internal and external validity of the ACES (Bethell et al., 2017). The researchers found that a single-factor model of the National Survey of Children’s Health-Adverse Childhood Experiences Survey (NSCH-ACEs), a variation of the original ACES measure, fit the data well (chi-square = 44 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  312.84; p <.01). Support for the predictive validity of the instrument was reported with significant odds ratio increases in behavioral, emotional, or mental problems as ACES scores increased. Predictive validity was also supported with critical education variables. Individuals with lower ACES scores were more likely to receive higher scores on a measure of school engagement. Compared to low ACES respondents, those with higher ACES scores were more likely to have repeated a grade in school. Concurrent validity has been demonstrated via correlation between total scores and subscale scores on the Adverse Childhood Experience International Questionnaire (ACE IQ) and the Childhood Trauma Questionnaire (CTQ) in international samples (Kazeem, 2015). Kazeem (2015) reported a total score correlation of r = 0.72 between the ACE IQ and CTQ. Subscale score correlations ranged from r = 0.23 for the Relationship with Parents/Guardians ACE IQ subscale and the Emotional Neglect subscale of the CTQ to r = 0.65 for the Family Environment ACE IQ subscale and the Sexual Abuse CTQ subscale (Kazeem, 2015). The ACES served as a predictor variable in this study and the Cronbach’s alpha in the current study was 0.87, as seen in Table 2.  Gender Minority Stress and Resilience Scale – Internalized Transphobia (Testa et al., 2015) The Internalized Transphobia (IT) subscale of the Gender Minority Stress and Resilience Scale (Testa et al., 2015) was used as a mediator variable to assess the associations of internalized transphobia, adverse childhood experiences, and intimate partner violence victimization in adulthood (see Appendix C). The Cronbach’s alpha in the current study was 0.91, as seen in Table 2. The IT is an 8-item, 5-point Likert-type scale that is part of the 60-item Gender Minority Stress and Resilience Scale. Sample items include, “I resent my gender identity or expression” and, “When I think about my gender identity or expression, I feel unhappy.” 45 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  Response options range from 0 (Strongly Disagree) to 4 (Strongly Agree). Scoring is summative, with total higher scores indicating greater degrees of internalized transphobia.  Internal consistency reliabilities for the IT subscale range from 0.89 to 0.90 in international contexts (Cronin et al., 2019; Scandurra et al., 2020) to 0.91 in the standardization sample (Testa et al., 2015) to 0.92 with adolescent participants in the United States (Hidalgo et al., 2019). The IT subscale has demonstrated evidence of convergent validity with measures of perceived life stress (r = 0.39 in Scandurra et al., 2020; r = 0.47 in Testa et al., 2015). Using general and gender-specific parental support as a proxy for life stress, Hidalgo and colleagues (2019) reported evidence of convergent validity of the IT subscale via inverse correlations to support, indicating that those endorsing more internalized transphobia also endorsed less general parental support (r = -0.36) and less gender-specific parental affirmation (r = -0.40).  Criterion validity was reported with the standardization sample via correlations between the subscales and measures of depression (r = 0.49) and social anxiety (r = 0.38; Testa et al., 2015). In a standardization sample conducted with Italian transgender participants, criterion validity of the IT subscale was supported via correlations with measures of depression (r = 0.35) and generalized anxiety (r = 0.42; Scandurra et al., 2020). When employed with an adolescent sample, researchers provided support for criterion validity for the IT subscale with measures of depression (r = 0.39) and social anxiety (r = 0.34; Hidalgo et al., 2019). Discriminant validity for the IT subscale was supported via weak to moderate correlations with scales measuring life stress and interpersonal experiences (Testa et al., 2015). These findings provide support for the unique nature of gender-related stress and highlight the distinction of gender minority stress from general life stressors.        Demographics Questionnaire  46 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  Participants also completed an 8-item demographic survey (see Appendix D). Participants reported a variety of demographic information, including age, socioeconomic status, relationship status, race/ethnicity, geographic location, and education level. Finally, participants reported their sexual orientation and gender identity. Consistent with previous literature (Anderson et al., 2017; Gonzalez-Guarda et al., 2016), sexual orientation identity was asked as an open-ended question, allowing for participants to self-identify. Similarly, gender identity was assessed using an open-ended question (Watson et al., 2019). These items were later quantitatively and qualitatively coded. Items were qualitatively coded by collapsing synonyms into one category, such as including responses of “genderfluid” and “gender nonbinary” in the same category of Nonbinary. Quantitatively, responses were categorized and dummy coded for ease of analysis.  Procedure  Participants were recruited via convenience sampling using Qualtrics Panel Studies. Qualtrics Panel Studies are frequently utilized for participant recruitment in behavioral and social sciences research (Cogan et al., 2020; Gillig et al., 2018; Zickgraf & Ellis, 2018). By using marketing research panels with respondents who have previously agreed to participate on a panel, Qualtrics Panel Studies quickly recruits participants with specified characteristics. Participants are pre-screened by Qualtrics to mitigate attrition rates and stereotyped responding. Qualtrics Panel Studies have frequently been used with difficult-to-reach populations, including transgender individuals (Cogan et al., 2020), people with disordered eating behaviors (Zickgraf & Ellis, 2018), and attitudinal research towards minoritized populations (Gillig et al., 2018). Qualtrics further expedites survey research by having panelists input their demographic information at the outset of their participation on panels, thus streamlining their ability to quickly 47 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  identify and recruit the appropriate participants. Participants in the current study were recruited through three initial soft launches of the survey as well as two waves of full recruitment. Interested respondents began their participation by clicking a check box indicating their informed consent documenting their role in the study, any potential risks and benefits, confidentiality, crisis contact information, and compensation. Participants completed four measures, including the CTS2S (Straus & Douglas, 2004), ACES (Felitti et al., 1998), the IT subscale of the Gender Minority Stress and Resilience Scale (Testa et al., 2015), and an 8-item demographics questionnaire. The CTS2S, ACES, and IT measures were presented in a counterbalanced order. Each measure included a written instruction page prior to presentation of the measure itself. Qualtrics Panel Studies participants were compensated directly through the survey engine.  Finally, participants were directed to a debriefing page detailing the purpose of the study and were provided with a list of counseling and crisis resources should they experience any distress from participation. All participants were provided with national service options and resources for IPV. Respondents were encouraged to utilize mental health resources as needed and to contact study personnel if they wished for their data to be withdrawn from the study or needed further assistance. Attentiveness in responding was evaluated via sporadic fidelity checks throughout each instrument. To protect the safety of participants and to maximize disclosure, participants will be encouraged to take the survey in a private location when they are alone.       48 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  CHAPTER 3 Results  The purpose of the current study was to determine the relation between adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) and intimate partner violence (IPV) in non-cisgender populations. The current analyses aimed to better understand the possible mediation role of internalized transphobia (IT) between ACES and IPV.   This research was a cross-sectional, single distribution survey, quantitative design. Participants completed a one-time survey via Qualtrics survey software. The study hypotheses were:  H1: There will be a significant, positive correlation between adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) and IPV experiences in adulthood.  H2: There will be a significant, positive correlation between IT and IPV experiences in adulthood.  H3: The relationship between adverse childhood experiences and intimate partner violence will be mediated by internalized transphobia.  The Statistical Package for Social Sciences version 25 (SPSS) software was employed to perform statistical analyses for the study (SPSS; I.B.M. Corp, 2017). Correlational analyses were used to understand the relationships between the three main variables of the study – ACES, IT, and IPV. This research also utilized regression analyses to determine if internalized transphobia mediated the associations between childhood adversity and intimate partner violence. There were several control variables used in this study, including race, sexual orientation identity, and gender identity. This chapter presents the preliminary and primary analyses of the study.  Preliminary Analyses 49 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  Tests of Statistical Assumptions To perform a mediated regression, the following assumptions must be met: normality, linearity, homogeneity of error variance, and independence of errors. The data were analyzed preliminarily via bivariate correlations between predictors to ensure that there are no concerns with multicollinearity. Multicollinearity exists when there is redundancy between predictor variables, therefore undermining the statistical significance of the test (Judd et al., 2017). The data were then analyzed for linearity, homogeneity of variance, and normality. Linearity is necessary for regression analyses as it demonstrates a linear relationship between the predictor variable and the outcome variable. Homogeneity of variance must be present for the use of multiple regression as this indicates equivalent variability in errors across the distribution (Judd et al., 2017). Finally, the data must evidence a normal distribution. After ensuring that the data met the requirements of the statistical assumptions, descriptive statistics were analyzed.     Descriptive Statistics  Descriptive statistics were calculated for the ACES, GMSRS, and CTS2S. Table 2 depicts the descriptive statistics calculated for the main study measures. The ACES had a mean score of 3.46 (SD = 1.88), indicating that participants reported an average of 3.5 adverse events prior to age eighteen. The IT subscale of the GMSRS yielded an average score of 20.76 (SD = 9.10), with responses ranging from 0 (Strongly Disagree) to 4 (Strongly Agree), indicating that participants reported moderate internalized transphobia. The CTS2S demonstrated a mean of 25.70 (SD = 27.71), indicating that participants reported roughly 25 incidences of conflict tactics occurring within the past year. Responses for each individual conflict tactic ranged from 0 (This has never happened) to 25 (More than 20 times in the past year). After coding, the possible 50 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  range on the CTS2S spans from 0 to 256. As such, participants in the current study endorsed conflict tactics in the lowest 10% frequency. Bivariate Correlation Analyses A series of bivariate correlations were conducted to discern the relationships between the study variables, as seen in Table 3. Three significant and positive associations were found in 51 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  these analyses. First, there was a significant and positive association between ACEs and IT (r = 0.18, p = .04), meaning that as the number of adverse childhood experiences increased, so too did respondents’ endorsement of internalized transphobia. This finding supports the first study hypothesis, which stated that there would be a significant, positive correlation between ACEs and IPV experiences. Finally, a significant, positive association was found between IT and CTS2S scores (r = 0.26, p < .01). This finding indicates that higher endorsement of internalized transphobia was associated with higher endorsement of conflict tactics. This finding supports the second hypothesis of the study, which stated that there would be a significant, positive correlation between IT and IPV experiences. Model 1 demonstrates that ACEs significantly and positively predicts CTS2S scores (adj R2 = .05; SE = 26.93; β = .25; p < .01). Model 2 adds the control variables of sexual orientation, race, and gender identity, each of which used binary coding with 0 for the reference category and 1 for all other categories. This finding means that after controlling for differences in sexual orientation identity, racial identity, and gender identity, ACES scores were still predictive of endorsement of IPV experiences. Those endorsing childhood adversity were more likely to also endorse IPV experiences on the CTS2S. Conversely, those who did not endorse childhood adversity were less likely to also endorse IPV experiences on the CTS2S. Taken together, the regression analyses presented in Table 4 support the first hypothesis of the study. This finding means that after controlling for variations in sexual orientation identity, racial identity, and gender identity, IT was still predictive of endorsement of IPV experiences. Those 54 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  who endorsed more internalized transphobia also endorsed more IPV experiences. Conversely, those who endorsed less internalized transphobia also endorsed fewer IPV experiences. Taken together, the regression analyses presented in Table 5 support the second hypothesis of the study. This research also addressed a critical gap in the IPV literature by exploring the relationship of internalized transphobia with childhood adversity and intimate partner violence. Previous research has found that gender minority individuals report experiencing high rates of intimate partner violence (Breiding et al., 2015; Messinger, 2017; Peitzmeier et al., 2020). Participants in the current study reported similar IPV experiences in line with previous findings, with 96% of participants endorsing lifetime prevalence of any form of IPV. Nearly one-third (32.8%) of respondents endorsed experiencing lifetime sexual coercion from their intimate partner and nearly one-quarter (23.2%) reported lifetime physical aggression. These results align with previous research findings that approximately 33% of GM individuals living in the United States have experienced physical or sexual violence from an intimate partner (Keuroghlian et al., 2015; Messinger, 2017). One-fifth (20%) of participants endorsed lifetime experience of assault with injury and roughly two-thirds (66.4%) reported experiencing psychological aggression from their intimate partner.    Results from this study support the hypothesis that a significant positive correlation exists between ACEs and IPV experiences. This finding builds upon previous research indicating that experiences of childhood trauma are associated with intimate partner violence in adulthood. Specifically, previous research with sexual minority individuals has found that witnessing IPV at home and history of abuse in childhood predicted IPV in adulthood (Mason et al., 2016). This relationship holds true for cisgender heterosexual individuals (Anderson & Kras, 2005), as well as women experiencing incarceration (Jones et al., 2018), and those identifying as LGBTQ 59 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  (Messinger, 2017). Additionally, the current research supports previous findings that witnessing IPV in childhood leads individuals to expect and accept IPV as a normative part of their relationships in adulthood (Lee et al., 2016). Thus, it appears that experiencing adversity in childhood predisposes individuals identifying with a minoritized gender identity to victimization in their adult relationships. While theoretical, this finding may indicate that ACEs can shape expectations for adult relationships, such that those exposed to ACEs differentially anticipate violence in their intimate partnerships compared to those without ACEs. Modeling of relationship violence in the home during childhood may therefore shape perceptions of and expectations for violence in the fabric of future intimate partnerships (Anderson & Kras, 2005; Bandura, 1973).   Additionally, findings from the current study support the hypothesis that there is a significant, positive correlation between IT and IPV. This means that those who internalize stigma and discrimination related to their gender identity were more likely to report experiencing intimate partner violence. Similar to the expectations for relational violence stemming from childhood trauma, it is possible that internalized shame regarding one’s gender identity leads to expectations of victimization. These individuals may internalize the erroneous belief that because of their gender identity, they are less worthy of affirming and non-abusive relationships compared to their cisgender peers (Rood et al., 2017). Additionally, GM individuals who experience internalized transphobia may normalize experiences of violence as a typical component of gender minority relationships. Thus, these individuals may fail to recognize violence when it occurs in their relationships and may anticipate relational aggression as a normative part of non-cisgender partnerships. Previous qualitative research has found that internalized transphobia is associated with increased expectations and acceptance of 60 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  interpersonal victimization (Rood et al., 2017). Therefore, it appears that individuals who identify as GM expect victimization, both broadly and within their romantic relationships. Given the small and tight-knit nature of GM communities (Bockting et al., 2020; Hidalgo et al., 2019), gender minority individuals may further normalize their experiences of IPV through discussion with other GM community members, thereby creating a culture of identity violence expectations and acceptance.  Further, GM survivors of IPV have reported that both internal and external shame related to gender identity serves as a barrier to not only disclosing IPV, but also recognizing IPV behaviors (Everhart & Hunnicutt, 2014; Kurdyla, 2021). Thus, those who experience IPV are less likely to discuss their concerns with others. These survivors are also less likely to identify their relationship experiences as abusive. Many GM survivors report difficulty recognizing IPV in their relationships and that this impacts their ability to reach out for support within systems that are designed for cisgender heterosexual survivors (Everhart & Hunnicutt, 2014). Gender minority individuals may therefore be less likely to access support from police and emergency housing organizations due to concerns that systemic support will be unavailable to them. Relatedly, GM survivors may also avoid systems-level support and interventions due to fear of discrimination and further violence within structures designed to support victims (Hendricks & Testa, 2012; Hidalgo et al., 2019). These factors comprise the foundation of minority stress. The pathway from internalized transphobia to intimate partner violence can be understood through the minority stress model (Hendricks & Testa, 2012) in which gender identity-related adverse experiences foster expectations for future victimization and internalized shame (Scheer et al., 2020). Many adverse experiences related to gender identity occur within oppressive systems that do not offer equitable care to GM individuals and also outrightly 61 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  discriminate and propagate violence against those identifying as gender diverse. In the context of the current study, the gender minority stress pathway indicates that the process of internalizing discriminatory self-image related to gender identity poses a specific risk for individuals to experience subsequent intimate partner victimization.   While unexpected, the findings from this study did not support the hypothesis that IT would mediate the relationship between ACEs and IPV. The data indicates that IT was trending towards significance. However, the independent associations between ACEs and IPV, as well as IT and IPV, were stronger. While this finding does not support hypothesis three in the current study, this data nevertheless provides new insight into the topography of victimizations experienced by GM individuals. Previous work has found a positive association between internalized heterosexism and IPV shame in sexual minority women (Thaggard & Montayre, 2019). It is possible that the process of internalizing identity shame presents differently for GM individuals, such that IT does not predict IPV shame. Further, systemic barriers and identity oppression may impact GM survivors’ ability to name their experiences as abusive. Further, findings from the current study provide additional support for the pervasiveness of childhood adversity among those identifying as gender minorities. Sixteen percent of participants endorsed at least one adverse childhood experience, with 52% endorsing four or more ACEs. This finding surpasses that found by Craig and colleagues (2020), in which 43% of LGBTQ+ participants ages 14-29 endorsed experiencing four or more ACEs. In the original ACES study, Felitti and colleagues (1998) reported that 6.2% of participants endorsed experiencing four or more ACEs. Similarly, a nationally representative sample in England found that 9% of participants reported experiencing four or more ACEs (Bellis et al., 2014). Finally, among social workers serving children in the Northeastern United States, 15.9% of participants 62 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  endorsed a history of four or more ACEs (Esaki & Larkin, 2013). Extant research indicates that irrespective of gender identity, those who report four or more ACEs are more likely to experience a sequelae of negative health outcomes in adulthood, including mood disorders, obesity, poor cardiac health, and suicidality (Brown et al., 2017; Clements-Nolle et al., 2018; Dube et al., 2001; Felitti et al., 1998; Forster et al., 2018). This finding is especially elevated for those identifying as non-cisgender (Schnarrs et al., 2019; Tobin & Delaney, 2019).    Limitations  While this research provided novel insight into the experiences of gender diverse individuals, it is not without limitations. First, this study utilized self-report to gather participant data. As such, the accuracy of demographic items and responses to study instruments could not be verified. This research attempted to minimize the risk of obtaining erroneous responses from individuals by recruiting participants via Qualtrics Panel Studies. Qualtrics Panel Studies recruits participants who self-identified demographic characteristics prior to study enrollment (Cogan et al., 2020). While this recruitment strategy minimizes the risk of unqualified respondents from participating, response veracity for each individual participant cannot be guaranteed. Relatedly, this study utilized convenience sampling, which resulted in selection bias and limits the external validity of the findings.    Another limitation of the current study is access to the survey. Using Qualtrics Panel Studies requires participants to have access to the internet, which may restrict the range of participants from various socioeconomic statuses. The demographics of participants indicate a wide spectrum of class identification. The majority of participants (58.4%) endorsed earning $40,000 or less annually, while 41.6% reported earning $40,001 or more annually. Effort was made in the current study to recruit participants from across socioeconomic backgrounds. 63 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  However, the recruitment strategy nevertheless likely neglected to include those experiencing severe financial distress. Those who are extremely low-income likely did not have access to the survey and these individuals may be at the highest risk of experiencing IPV. Because of this, the current data may underrepresent the range and severity of IPV in the GM population.  Extant research has found that gender minority individuals living below the poverty line are among the most likely to experience violence, including intimate partner violence (Kattari et al., 2022; King et al., 2022). Additionally, gender minority individuals living below the poverty line are more likely to engage in survival crimes such as sex work (Cerezo et al., 2014). These individuals may experience a disproportionate amount of IPV due to overlapping areas of marginalization (Keuroghlian et al., 2015). Relatedly, those identifying as gender minorities are more likely to experience homelessness in youth, which has been linked to an increased endorsement of internalized transphobia and familial rejection (Keuroghlian et al., 2015; Koken et al., 2009). Thus, the current study may underrepresent the prevalence and severity of IPV, ACEs, and IT in gender minority individuals.   The current study is also limited by the relatively small sample size, which necessitated collapsing of gender identity categories and sexual orientation categories. With a larger sample, different identity groups could have been analyzed independently to provide deeper insight into the topography and prevalence of study variables across gender identities and sexual orientations. The collapsing of gender identities and sexual orientations was conducted after extensive consultation with existing research (Hatchel et al., 2018; Hughto et al., 2017; Messinger et al., 2021; Shipherd et al., 2011). Nevertheless, the nuance of variable expression across identities may have been muted due to the coding strategy employed in this research. It is possible that differences exist in IPV experiences for those identifying as nonbinary compared to 64 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  individuals who identify as transgender compared to transgender men and transgender women. With a larger sample size, the analyses could have tested for between-group differences in endorsement of study variables. Previous research with sexual minority women has found that internalized heterosexism and shame associated with IPV experiences contributed to lower rates of help-seeking and further IPV victimization (Thaggard & Montayre, 2019). It is possible that the small sample size in the current study precluded the detection of a similar trend with internalized transphobia.  Additionally, the brevity of the IT instrument may have not fully captured the experiences of participants, thus suppressing the potential mediating effect of IT in the relationship between ACEs and IPV. Further, a larger sample size would have allowed for more specific analysis of ACES items. Given that some ACEs are considered more severe than others (Andersen & Blosnich, 2013), individualized analysis could clarify how specific ACEs are correlated with IT and IPV. Additionally, many participants (64.8%) self-identified as White, with 35.2% identifying as non-White. While the representation of non-White participants is a strength of the current study, previous research indicates that those identifying as non-White experience higher rates of IPV (Reuter et al., 2017). As such, findings from the current study may not fully capture the experiences of survivors identifying as people of color. Findings from this work may therefore be less generalizable to non-White GM individuals.   Another limitation of the current study involves instrumentation. While the CTS2 and CTS2S are widely regarded as the gold standard in the field of intimate partner violence research, this instrument likely does not fully capture the IPV experiences of those identifying as gender minority. Recently, a scale was developed to specifically assess IPV experiences related to transgender identity. The Transgender Intimate Partner Violence scale (T-IPV; Peitzmeier et 65 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  al., 2021) includes items related to established IPV experiences as well as those specific to gender minority identity. This type of instrument can help further elucidate IPV experiences for those identifying as GM. The T-IPV includes items assessing for control and coercion of gender-affirming practices as well as verbal, physical, and sexual violence tactics that are specific to gendered body parts. By using the T-IPV, researchers can gain greater insight into not only the topography of IPV for GM individuals, but also the ways in which IT is related to the presentation of T-IPV.  Future Research Directions Future research should strive to recruit a larger sample size of participants holding a wider array of demographic diversity. Recruiting more participants may help elucidate the potential mediating role of internalized transphobia. Further, greater demographic diversity in a larger sample will help identify nuances in experience with study variables across different intersectional identities. For example, a larger study could parse apart experiences for participants identifying as gender nonbinary compared to those identifying as agender and genderfluid. Furthermore, recruiting participants from a wider range of socioeconomic classes could help in eliciting valuable information from those most impacted by childhood adversity, internalized transphobia, and intimate partner violence.   Additionally, future research should explore diverse instrumentation in the analysis of the study variables. Specifically, future research will benefit from utilizing the Transgender Intimate Partner Violence scale (T-IPV; Peitzmeier et al., 2021) as this scale was specifically developed to screen for IPV that is specific to transgender identity. This instrument was not used in the current research given that it was published after the proposal of this dissertation. Items on the T-IPV scale assess controlling behaviors enacted by one’s partner, including belittling of gender 66 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  identity, incorrect pronoun use, threats and behaviors related to outing an individual as transgender, and hiding or destroying gender-affirming items. Additionally, this scale includes items assessing when a partner pressures an individual to not pursue various aspects of transitioning and when a partner pressures an individual to present as a gender that does not match their gender identity (Peitzmeier et al., 2021). By using a GM-specific instrument, future research could provide greater insight into the relationships among ACEs, IT, and IPV.  Furthermore, analyzing the topography of IPV in digital landscapes could prove beneficial. Given the prevalence of social media and dating violence that occurs on various platforms, research on the topography of digital IPV for GM individuals could expand opportunities for prevention and intervention. Existing research indicates that those identifying as gender minorities experience and employ high rates of digital dating abuse tactics (Ellyson et al., 2021).    Subsequent research should also focus on the topography of IPV for gender minority college students. Research with the college population can include early intervention and prevention methods with the aim of decreasing the likelihood of future victimization. This may take the form of psychoeducational outreaches with pre-and-post outreach surveys to assess baseline knowledge of and experience with intimate partner violence.   Future research should also take a resiliency-based approach to better understand buffers for IPV and avenues for healing from various forms of adversity. Analysis using the resiliency subscales, Community Connectedness and Pride, on the GMSR measure (Testa et al., 2015) may prove particularly useful in underscoring the importance of community safety nets that may decrease the likelihood of experiencing IPV and/or promote growth and healing after experiencing violence. Similarly, the Pride subscale on the GMSR measure can provide novel 67 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  insight into how internalizing a sense of pride, rather than shame, regarding one’s gender identity can mitigate risk factors for violence victimization.   Relatedly, subsequent analyses can also use dyadic recruitment strategies to involve both partners. This recruitment strategy would necessitate modification for gender minority participants who are in polyamorous relationships. By recruiting both partners in the relationship, researchers can gain a fuller understanding of the experience of each study variable by both members of the dyad. This type of recruitment would be beneficial for additional intervention research focusing on building collaborative communication skills (Cook-Daniels, 2015). Given the value of community in minoritized communities, dyads participating in this type of intervention research could prove invaluable in disseminating collaborative communication techniques to their social circles, many of whom may also have experienced or be experiencing similar challenges.  Implications for Counseling Psychologists  Given the field’s focus on multicultural considerations and identity development, counseling psychologists are well-suited to provide care for those identifying as GM. Several implications for training and clinical practice can be gleaned from the current study. First, findings from this research underscore the importance of attending to risk factors for IPV among gender minority clients. Specifically, understanding the impact of childhood adversity on IPV in adulthood is particularly salient for GM clients. Those who have experienced ACEs demonstrate an elevated risk of experiencing IPV. As clinicians, it is imperative to understand how childhood adversity places our GM clients at greater risk of subsequent victimization. Given the stigma and discrimination associated with GM identity, those identifying as gender minorities may be less likely to seek support and protection from established agencies, including law enforcement and 68 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  legal systems. GM clients may therefore seek support and guidance from counseling psychologists. Counseling psychologists must therefore be aware of local resources and protections available to GM individuals.   Relatedly, doctoral training regarding the nuances of GM IPV will be beneficial to burgeoning counseling psychologists. This type of training can take the form of didactic seminars and clinical engagement with local gender minority communities. Further, given that individuals from minoritized backgrounds face numerous barriers to seeking psychological services (Spengler et al., 2023), community engagement may prove crucial in connecting GM individuals with affirming clinical services. Counseling psychology trainees and clinicians will benefit from providing community outreach across local LGBTQ+ spaces. Focusing on prevention and strengths-based approaches may prove especially beneficial. For example, clinicians and trainees can provide outreaches to the community that focus on boundary setting, consent, and communication as a preventive strategy in helping clients establish reciprocally affirming and positive relationships and recognize early indicators of potential abuse in intimate partnerships.  Previous research has found that those identifying as gender minorities may have little support in establishing awareness of collaborative problem-solving in intimate partnerships (Cook-Daniels, 2015). Thus, certain aspects of IPV may be reflective of knowledge deficits and not intentional abuse. Providing comprehensive and identity-inclusive psychoeducational outreaches to this community may help individuals identifying as gender minorities feel more empowered to engage in collaborative problem-solving in their intimate partnerships, thereby decreasing instances of IPV. Additionally, community outreach may take the form of providing 69 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  psychoeducational outreaches to local partner organizations, including law enforcement, healthcare providers, and temporary housing shelters, among others.    Additionally, clinicians should be aware of the ways in which internalized transphobia impacts the psychological well-being of GM individuals. While the current findings did not demonstrate mediation in the relationship between ACEs and IPV, the mediating effect of IT was trending towards significance. This trend indicates that with a larger sample size, IT may hold significance in mediating the relationship between ACEs and IPV. Further, while IT did not demonstrate significance in this research, this form of internalized shame has been found to significantly impact other facets of well-being among GM individuals, including increased suicidality, depression, and occupational impairment, among others (Lee et al., 2020; Mizock et al., 2017; Perez-Brumer et al., 2015; Testa et al., 2017).  Conclusion This study sought to understand the relationship between ACEs, IT, and IPV in individuals identifying as gender minorities. Extant research has consistently identified links between experiencing adversity in childhood and negative physical and mental health outcomes in adulthood (Brown et al., 2017; Clements-Nolle et al., 2018; Dube et al., 2001; Felitti et al., 1998; Forster et al., 2018). Across a wide variety of outcomes correlated with ACEs, both victimization and perpetration of intimate partner violence remains a public health crisis. The current study echoes previous research findings that those identifying as GM experience disproportionately high rates of IPV (Messinger, 2017; Peitzmeier et al., 2020). Similarly, this study extended previous findings that non-cisgender individuals experience ACEs at a rate equivalent, if not greater than, their cisgender counterparts (Baams, 2018; Juárez-Chávez et al., 2018; Schnarrs et al., 2019; Tobin & Delaney, 2019).  70 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  Extant literature has found internalized shame to be related to both ACEs and IPV (Rood et al., 2017; Thaggard & Montayre, 2019; Thomson & Jaque, 2018b). Given the salience of internalized transphobia in impacting various facets of wellness for non-cisgender individuals, this study sought to understand the role of IT in the relationship between ACEs and IPV experiences. While IT was not found to be a significant mediator between ACEs and IPV, these findings nevertheless illuminate the experiences of gender minority individuals with respect to the aforementioned variables. Significant relationships between ACEs and IPV and IT and IPV were identified.                 71 ACES AND IPV IN GM POPULATIONS  References Afifi, T. O., Mota, N., Sareen, J., & MacMillan, H. L. title: Adverse Childhood Experiences and Intimate Partner Violence in Gender Minority Populations
abstract: Childhood adversity has been linked to numerous health and mental health concerns in adulthood (Felitti et al., 1998). Among the many outcomes associated with adverse childhood experiences (ACEs), victimization and perpetration of intimate partner violence (IPV) remains a public health crisis. Research has found that those identifying as gender minority individuals are disproportionately impacted by IPV (Messinger, 2017; Peitzmeier et al., 2020). Further, gender minority individuals experience equivalent, if not higher, rates of ACEs when compared to their cisgender counterparts (Baams, 2018; Juárez-Chávez et al., 2018; Schnarrs et al., 2019; Tobin & Delaney, 2019). While many factors contribute to the pathway from ACEs to IPV, the role of internalized transphobia (IT) in this relation is poorly understood. However, previous research has underscored the role of internalized shame in relation to both ACEs and IPV (Rood et al., 2017; Thaggard & Montayre, 2019; Thomson & Jaque, 2018b). Internalized transphobia may therefore serve as a mediator in the relationship between adverse childhood experiences and intimate partner violence. Using a cross-sectional quantitative single administration survey design, this research aimed to better understand the relation between ACEs, IT, and IPV in adults identifying as gender minorities. This study used a mediated regression model to discern if internalized transphobia mediated the relationship between childhood adversity and intimate partner violence. Findings from this research indicated that while internalized transphobia did not mediate the relationship between ACEs and IPV, IT was still predictive of IPV. Endorsement of ACEs also predicted endorsement of IPV
